values.description:
* Currently the Vector3 config widget is only used for Joint axes and friction `fdir` in the model editor.

* Changing the preset updates the XYZ spins, and changing the spins updates the preset combo box

![axis_preset.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/150317150-axis_preset.png)

![axes_presets2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3603052064-axes_presets2.png)

values.description:
The logged in user name is displayed in the toolbar on the right. 

The screenshot icon and log-record icon have been moved to the left 

![login_status.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3547058655-login_status.png)

To manually test this:

1. follow instructions in rest-web plugin test [readme](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/40c4a2f966533a8dce6d085e5e346a9dcc99adf9/test/plugins/rest-web/readme.txt?at=rest_login_status&fileviewer=file-view-default) file and install the rest server. 

1. Launch gzserver and gzclient using the scripts in the folder

1. log in via the REST-web menu in the menubar with the credentials: `myuser` / `mypass`

1. the username should appear on the right side of the toolbar


jenkins [no gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/792/) - 1 style error and fixed in 40c4a2f

summary.html:
The logged in user name is displayed in the toolbar on the right.

The screenshot icon and log-record icon have been moved to the left

To manually test this:

  1. follow instructions in rest-web plugin test readme file and install the rest server.

  2. Launch gzserver and gzclient using the scripts in the folder

  3. log in via the REST-web menu in the menubar with the credentials: myuser / mypass

  4. the username should appear on the right side of the toolbar

jenkins no gpu - 1 style error and fixed in 40c4a2f

values.title: Remove minor version in gazebo filesystem paths

values.description:
It is sometimes useful to change the pose of a visual directly without changing the pose of its parent link and without relying on a joint. In our case, we needed to rotate the blades of a drone without producing any effect on the physics world.

In order to do that, we added three member functions. `Link::VisualId()` is used to retrieve the unique ID of a visual from its name. `Link::VisualPose()` is used to get the pose of a visual from its ID. And, finally, `Link::SetVisualPose()` is used to set the pose of a visual.

With the help of these functions, any server-side plugin can set the pose of a visual in the scene. The choice of the time frame to call them is left to each plugin.
values.title: Set the pose of a visual

summary.raw:
It is sometimes useful to change the pose of a visual directly without changing the pose of its parent link and without relying on a joint. In our case, we needed to rotate the blades of a drone without producing any effect on the physics world.

In order to do that, we added three member functions. `Link::VisualId()` is used to retrieve the unique ID of a visual from its name. `Link::VisualPose()` is used to get the pose of a visual from its ID. And, finally, `Link::SetVisualPose()` is used to set the pose of a visual.

With the help of these functions, any server-side plugin can set the pose of a visual in the scene. The choice of the time frame to call them is left to each plugin.
summary.html:
It is sometimes useful to change the pose of a visual directly without changing the pose of its parent link and without relying on a joint. In our case, we needed to rotate the blades of a drone without producing any effect on the physics world.

In order to do that, we added three member functions. Link::VisualId() is used to retrieve the unique ID of a visual from its name. Link::VisualPose() is used to get the pose of a visual from its ID. And, finally, Link::SetVisualPose() is used to set the pose of a visual.

With the help of these functions, any server-side plugin can set the pose of a visual in the scene. The choice of the time frame to call them is left to each plugin.

values.description:
* fix memory corruption

    Map assignment coupled with a right operand that deletes the map entry to be assigned leads to undefined behaviour, and according to the compiler implementation, to "use after free".

* fix indentation for last commit
values.title: Fix_send_message (backport of pull request #1951)

summary.raw:
* fix memory corruption

    Map assignment coupled with a right operand that deletes the map entry to be assigned leads to undefined behaviour, and according to the compiler implementation, to "use after free".

* fix indentation for last commit
summary.html:
• fix memory corruption

    Map assignment coupled with a right operand that deletes the map entry to be assigned leads to undefined behaviour, and according to the compiler implementation, to "use after free".

  • fix indentation for last commit

values.description:
fix for a couple of issues related to visual transparency

- issue #1726 - launch a world with semi-transparent model and it's rendered opaque

- right click on model and select View > Transparent on a semi-transparent model and then do the same again to turn it off -> the model is now opaque when it should revert back to semi-transparent 

 
added new `DerivedTransparency()` function and test

jenkins:

[abi](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any_to_any-abichecker-vivid-amd64/36/) - ok

[gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/590/testReport/) - ok

added new DerivedTransparency() function and test

values.description:
I've confirmed that this allows the sdformat default branch to be compiled against gazebo5:

* http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-sdformat-any-devel-trusty-amd64/53 (this build is wrongly marked as a failure, though it's compilation and most of the tests succeeded)

This can be merged forward to gazebo6 and default.

I forgot to mention that this is motivated by a failure to build gazebo against the default branch of sdformat since [sdformat pull request 233](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/233/update-version-in-default-to-400/diff) was merged.

* http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-sdformat-default-devel-trusty-amd64/59/

[Jenkins ran successfully](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-sdformat-any-devel-trusty-amd64/54/) though it is marked as a failure for an unknown reason.

Jenkins ran successfully though it is marked as a failure for an unknown reason.

values.description:
We have built custom debs of bullet 2.82 for trusty that have double precision enabled, but the debs in Ubuntu vivid use single precision. It still works but with less accuracy and with [some test failures](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-vivid-amd64-gpu-intel/1/) (note the test names ending in `/1`). This PR relaxes test expectations to allow them to pass with single-precision bullet.

* In several instances where `EXPECT_DOUBLE_EQ` is used, I just change it to `EXPECT_FLOAT_EQ` for all physics engines. This slightly weakens the test for engines that are using double precision, but I think it's close enough.

* In other instances, I check the size of `btScalar` and set different tolerances based on trial and error to make the tests pass.

* In the contact_sensor test, the normal had correct magnitude but opposite sign, so I take the absolute value.

The tests now pass in a [gazebo-any-devel-vivid jenkins job](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-vivid-amd64-gpu-intel/4/).
values.title: Relax physics tolerances for single-precision bullet

summary.raw:
We have built custom debs of bullet 2.82 for trusty that have double precision enabled, but the debs in Ubuntu vivid use single precision. It still works but with less accuracy and with [some test failures](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-vivid-amd64-gpu-intel/1/) (note the test names ending in `/1`). This PR relaxes test expectations to allow them to pass with single-precision bullet.

* In several instances where `EXPECT_DOUBLE_EQ` is used, I just change it to `EXPECT_FLOAT_EQ` for all physics engines. This slightly weakens the test for engines that are using double precision, but I think it's close enough.

* In other instances, I check the size of `btScalar` and set different tolerances based on trial and error to make the tests pass.

* In the contact_sensor test, the normal had correct magnitude but opposite sign, so I take the absolute value.

The tests now pass in a [gazebo-any-devel-vivid jenkins job](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-vivid-amd64-gpu-intel/4/).
summary.html:
We have built custom debs of bullet 2.82 for trusty that have double precision enabled, but the debs in Ubuntu vivid use single precision. It still works but with less accuracy and with some test failures (note the test names ending in /1). This PR relaxes test expectations to allow them to pass with single-precision bullet.

  • In several instances where EXPECT_DOUBLE_EQ is used, I just change it to EXPECT_FLOAT_EQ for all physics engines. This slightly weakens the test for engines that are using double precision, but I think it's close enough.

  • In other instances, I check the size of btScalar and set different tolerances based on trial and error to make the tests pass.

  • In the contact_sensor test, the normal had correct magnitude but opposite sign, so I take the absolute value.

The tests now pass in a gazebo-any-devel-vivid jenkins job.

values.description:
Restore a minimum height of Gazebo window inferior to ~700 pixels .

Solves #!/osrf/gazebo/issues/1706 .

Furthermore, we add a warning when a user request in a gui.ini file a window width or height that is below the minimum.

We add a tests that check that the minimum size of the window is lower then some value (for the moment 700 pixels for the width and 710 pixels to the height).

See related discussion: https://bitbucket.org/traversaro/gazebo-fork/commits/d577d3ce27723f3b0db86946c944a1b412266d62 .
values.title: Fix minimum window height

summary.raw:
Restore a minimum height of Gazebo window inferior to ~700 pixels .

Solves #!/osrf/gazebo/issues/1706 .

Furthermore, we add a warning when a user request in a gui.ini file a window width or height that is below the minimum.

We add a tests that check that the minimum size of the window is lower then some value (for the moment 700 pixels for the width and 710 pixels to the height).

See related discussion: https://bitbucket.org/traversaro/gazebo-fork/commits/d577d3ce27723f3b0db86946c944a1b412266d62 .
summary.html:
Restore a minimum height of Gazebo window inferior to ~700 pixels .

Solves #!/osrf/gazebo/issues/1706 .

Furthermore, we add a warning when a user request in a gui.ini file a window width or height that is below the minimum.

We add a tests that check that the minimum size of the window is lower then some value (for the moment 700 pixels for the width and 710 pixels to the height).

See related discussion: https://bitbucket.org/traversaro/gazebo-fork/commits/d577d3ce27723f3b0db86946c944a1b412266d62 .

values.description:
# Partial video of new joint creation:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JAMdLo0CadU

# This pull request 

* Shouldn't change the current behaviour

* Renames `mouseJoint` to `newJoint`, because it won't be created only with the mouse anymore

* Removes `selectedVis` and uses `newJoint->parent` whenever it makes sense

* Add `active` style sheet to config widget (the green one you can briefly see in the beginning of the video)

* Fix tests which were broken since pull request #1954 (# of combo boxes)

* Handle `MouseMove` events like the others

*  `RemoveJoint` now removes `newJoint` if a joint name is not given

*  Add `SetParentLink` and `SetChildLink`

# CI

[no gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/827) clean

values.description:
The default behaviour of the user camera in follow mode is not convenient with aircrafts. This pull request introduces a new `static` mode that intends to fix this issue.

A new `<follow_model>` section must be added to `<world><gui><camera>` in sdformat (see related pull request [#238](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/238/new-section/diff) in sdformat).

With default parameters, the camera will remain at a distance of 8 meters from the tracked model (current behaviour of gazebo):

    <?xml version="1.0" ?>
    <sdf version="1.5">
      <world name="default">
        <gui>
          <camera name="user_camera">
            <follow_model>
              <static>false</static>
              <distance>8</distance>
            </follow_model>
          </camera>
        </gui>
      </world>
    </sdf>

In this other example, the camera will remain at the same position from the model (3 meters behind and 1 meter above):

    <?xml version="1.0" ?>
    <sdf version="1.5">
      <world name="default">
        <gui>
          <camera name="user_camera">
            <follow_model>
              <static>true</static>
              <xyz>-3 0 1</xyz>
            </follow_model>
          </camera>
        </gui>
      </world>
    </sdf>

Finally, we introduce the `<relative>` element whose default value is `true`. When `<static>` is true, this element specifies whether the coordinates provided by `<xyz>` are relative to the model reference frame or the world reference frame. In this last example, the user camera will stay at 10 meters above the origin:

    <?xml version="1.0" ?>
    <sdf version="1.5">
      <world name="default">
        <gui>
          <camera name="user_camera">
            <follow_model>
              <static>true</static>
              <relative>false</relative>
              <xyz>0 0 10</xyz>
            </follow_model>
          </camera>
        </gui>
      </world>
    </sdf>

In either mode, the camera always tries to remain orientated towards the model being tracked. When the camera is static and its position is relative, it also remains in the horizontal plane of the model (pitch and roll are ignored). All three parameters are configurable at runtime in gzclient.
values.title: Static camera when following a model

summary.html:
The default behaviour of the user camera in follow mode is not convenient with aircrafts. This pull request introduces a new static mode that intends to fix this issue.

A new <follow_model> section must be added to <world><gui><camera> in sdformat (see related pull request #238 in sdformat).

With default parameters, the camera will remain at a distance of 8 meters from the tracked model (current behaviour of gazebo):

<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.5">
  <world name="default">
    <gui>
      <camera name="user_camera">
        <follow_model>
          <static>false</static>
          <distance>8</distance>
        </follow_model>
      </camera>
    </gui>
  </world>
</sdf>

In this other example, the camera will remain at the same position from the model (3 meters behind and 1 meter above):

<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.5">
  <world name="default">
    <gui>
      <camera name="user_camera">
        <follow_model>
          <static>true</static>
          <xyz>-3 0 1</xyz>
        </follow_model>
      </camera>
    </gui>
  </world>
</sdf>

Finally, we introduce the <relative> element whose default value is true. When <static> is true, this element specifies whether the coordinates provided by <xyz> are relative to the model reference frame or the world reference frame. In this last example, the user camera will stay at 10 meters above the origin:

<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.5">
  <world name="default">
    <gui>
      <camera name="user_camera">
        <follow_model>
          <static>true</static>
          <relative>false</relative>
          <xyz>0 0 10</xyz>
        </follow_model>
      </camera>
    </gui>
  </world>
</sdf>

In either mode, the camera always tries to remain orientated towards the model being tracked. When the camera is static and its position is relative, it also remains in the horizontal plane of the model (pitch and roll are ignored). All three parameters are configurable at runtime in gzclient.

values.description:
This is a continuation of the work to update inertia properties graphically, described in this [design document](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/src/default/inertia_resize/inertia_resize.md). Previously, pull request #1909 added a test for modifying mass and center-of-mass location over the `~/model/modify` topic. This pull request adds a test for modifying the diagonal moment of inertia terms. Modifying the off-diagonal terms (per issue #880) will require a bit more work.

The test uses a new world called `pendulum_axes.world`, created from an erb file. It has several boxes pinned at one end to the world, with a variety of link frame rotations and axis orientations. The test identifies the length of the pendulum and moment of inertia along the rotation axis and computes an expected frequency of oscillation (which is [derived in this ipython notebook](http://nbviewer.ipython.org/urls/bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/raw/modify_moment_of_inertia/test/integration/physics_msgs_inertia.ipynb)).

Also, I made a small change to the `joint_friction_demo` world by adding physically accurate inertias to the links with prismatic joints. This doesn't affect the dynamics, since those links are prevented from rotating by the prismatic joint, but it makes the inertia visualization look nicer.

The test passes for ODE, bullet, and DART, but is disabled for simbody. The [jenkins-nvidia-dart4 build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/87/) is happy.
values.title: Update inertia properties during simulation: part 2

summary.raw:
This is a continuation of the work to update inertia properties graphically, described in this [design document](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/src/default/inertia_resize/inertia_resize.md). Previously, pull request #1909 added a test for modifying mass and center-of-mass location over the `~/model/modify` topic. This pull request adds a test for modifying the diagonal moment of inertia terms. Modifying the off-diagonal terms (per issue #880) will require a bit more work.

The test uses a new world called `pendulum_axes.world`, created from an erb file. It has several boxes pinned at one end to the world, with a variety of link frame rotations and axis orientations. The test identifies the length of the pendulum and moment of inertia along the rotation axis and computes an expected frequency of oscillation (which is [derived in this ipython notebook](http://nbviewer.ipython.org/urls/bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/raw/modify_moment_of_inertia/test/integration/physics_msgs_inertia.ipynb)).

Also, I made a small change to the `joint_friction_demo` world by adding physically accurate inertias to the links with prismatic joints. This doesn't affect the dynamics, since those links are prevented from rotating by the prismatic joint, but it makes the inertia visualization look nicer.

The test passes for ODE, bullet, and DART, but is disabled for simbody. The [jenkins-nvidia-dart4 build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/87/) is happy.
summary.html:
This is a continuation of the work to update inertia properties graphically, described in this design document. Previously, pull request #1909 added a test for modifying mass and center-of-mass location over the ~/model/modify topic. This pull request adds a test for modifying the diagonal moment of inertia terms. Modifying the off-diagonal terms (per issue #880) will require a bit more work.

The test uses a new world called pendulum_axes.world, created from an erb file. It has several boxes pinned at one end to the world, with a variety of link frame rotations and axis orientations. The test identifies the length of the pendulum and moment of inertia along the rotation axis and computes an expected frequency of oscillation (which is derived in this ipython notebook).

Also, I made a small change to the joint_friction_demo world by adding physically accurate inertias to the links with prismatic joints. This doesn't affect the dynamics, since those links are prevented from rotating by the prismatic joint, but it makes the inertia visualization look nicer.

The test passes for ODE, bullet, and DART, but is disabled for simbody. The jenkins-nvidia-dart4 build is happy.

values.description:
Gazebo does not have a Wind class. This pull request provides a simple Wind class whose default behavior can be overriden by a plugin.

The global wind parameters are defined in the SDF file, they consist of the wind linear velocity. The Wind class is instantiated once during World initialization. A plugin can access the Wind singleton with ```World::GetWind()``` and change its method of computation by specifying a custom function with ```Wind::SetLinearVelFunc(std::function<ignition::math::Vector3d (const WindPtr &, const Entity *_entity)> _linearVelFunc)```.

The wind velocity at a link position in space is updated before each simulation iteration by calling ```Wind::WorldLinearVel(const Entity *_entity)``` during world update. This method takes the entity itself as a parameter and returns the wind linear velocity at entity's current location. This operation is only performed if the wind is enabled globally and if the link is defined to be affected by it. Internally, this method calls the function that was determined by ```Wind::SetLinearVelFunc(...)```.

If it gets accepted, this feature would require two new optional sections in the link and world SDF files  (see related pull request [#240](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/240/new-element/diff) in sdformat):

```
#!xml
<world name="default">
  <wind>
    <linear_velocity>11 11 0</linear_velocity> <!-- Wind linear velocity -->
  </wind>
  <model name="model">
    <link name="link">
      <wind>true</<wind>
    </link>
  </model>
</world>
```

At the client side, the wind parameters are displayed in the property tree browser. Wind velocity for a selected link only appears in its corresponding property tree if the wind is enabled for this link.

A plugin example can be found in `plugins/WindPlugin.cc`. Its corresponding world is `worlds/wind_demo.world`.
values.title: Added wind support

The global wind parameters are defined in the SDF file, they consist of the wind linear velocity. The Wind class is instantiated once during World initialization. A plugin can access the Wind singleton with ```World::GetWind()``` and change its method of computation by specifying a custom function with ```Wind::SetLinearVelFunc(std::function<ignition::math::Vector3d (const WindPtr &, const Entity *_entity)> _linearVelFunc)```.

The wind velocity at a link position in space is updated before each simulation iteration by calling ```Wind::WorldLinearVel(const Entity *_entity)``` during world update. This method takes the entity itself as a parameter and returns the wind linear velocity at entity's current location. This operation is only performed if the wind is enabled globally and if the link is defined to be affected by it. Gazebo does not have a Wind class. This pull request provides a simple Wind class whose default behavior can be overriden by a plugin.

The global wind parameters are defined in the SDF file, they consist of the wind linear velocity. The Wind class is instantiated once during World initialization. A plugin can access the Wind singleton with World::GetWind() and change its method of computation by specifying a custom function with Wind::SetLinearVelFunc(std::function<ignition::math::Vector3d (const WindPtr &, const Entity *_entity)> _linearVelFunc).

The wind velocity at a link position in space is updated before each simulation iteration by calling Wind::WorldLinearVel(const Entity *_entity) during world update. This method takes the entity itself as a parameter and returns the wind linear velocity at entity's current location. This operation is only performed if the wind is enabled globally and if the link is defined to be affected by it. Internally, this method calls the function that was determined by Wind::SetLinearVelFunc(...).

If it gets accepted, this feature would require two new optional sections in the link and world SDF files (see related pull request #240 in sdformat):

<world name="default">
  <wind>
    <linear_velocity>11 11 0</linear_velocity> <!-- Wind linear velocity -->
  </wind>
  <model name="model">
    <link name="link">
      <wind>true</<wind>

</world>

At the client side, the wind parameters are displayed in the property tree browser. Wind velocity for a selected link only appears in its corresponding property tree if the wind is enabled for this link.

A plugin example can be found in plugins/WindPlugin.cc. Its corresponding world is worlds/wind_demo.world.

values.description:
Undo for reset commands (reset world, reset model poses, reset time)

User commands are handled a bit differently in this pull request than the user commands introduced in pull request #1934. 

Before, the command action itself and the "user command" which is registered for undo were sent in parallel. This was causing issues due to the order in which the messages are handled. The issues are harder to reproduce with some commands.

![undoSync1.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3634482620-undoSync1.png)

We want to make sure the user command is registered before the action takes effect (to save the world state before the command). The new approach is to send the "action" inside the user command, and republish that message from `UserCmdManager` in the server. 

![undoSync2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/743430199-undoSync2.png)

If this pull request gets merged, I'll make a new pull request converting the former user commands to the same style.

Some considerations:

1. Other subscribers to the "action" messages shouldn't be affected

1. This makes the same information be published twice (the first time it's a message within a message)

1. `user_cmd.proto` might get very big once all the command types are implemented. Consider extending the message

[CI](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20coverage%20jobs/job/gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64/477/) ok
values.title: Undo resets

User commands are handled a bit differently in this pull request than the user commands introduced in pull request #1934. 

Before, the command action itself and the "user command" which is registered for undo were sent in parallel. This was causing issues due to the order in which the messages are handled. The issues are harder to reproduce with some commands.

![undoSync1.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3634482620-undoSync1.png)

We want to make sure the user command is registered before the action takes effect (to save the world state before the command). The new approach is to send the "action" inside the user command, and republish that message from `UserCmdManager` in the server. 

![undoSync2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/743430199-undoSync2.png)

If this pull request gets merged, I'll make a new pull request converting the former user commands to the same style.

Some considerations:

1. Other subscribers to the "action" messages shouldn't be affected

1. This makes the same information be published twice (the first time it's a message within a message)

1. `user_cmd.proto` might get very big once all the command types are implemented. Consider extending the message

[CI](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20coverage%20jobs/job/gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64/477/) ok
summary.html:
Undo for reset commands (reset world, reset model poses, reset time)

User commands are handled a bit differently in this pull request than the user commands introduced in pull request #1934.

Before, the command action itself and the "user command" which is registered for undo were sent in parallel. This was causing issues due to the order in which the messages are handled. The issues are harder to reproduce with some commands.

We want to make sure the user command is registered before the action takes effect (to save the world state before the command). The new approach is to send the "action" inside the user command, and republish that message from UserCmdManager in the server.

If this pull request gets merged, I'll make a new pull request converting the former user commands to the same style.

Some considerations:

  1. Other subscribers to the "action" messages shouldn't be affected

  2. This makes the same information be published twice (the first time it's a message within a message)

  3. user_cmd.proto might get very big once all the command types are implemented. Consider extending the message

CI ok

values.description:
This pull request provides a base class Atmosphere and a derived class AdiabaticAtmosphere that implements an adiabatic atmosphere model.

The global atmosphere parameters are defined in the SDF file, they consist of the temperature, pressure, mass density, and temperature gradient at sea level. The Atmosphere class is instantiated once during World initialization. A plugin can access the Atmosphere singleton with ```World::Atmosphere()``` and query its values at different altitudes. For now, only one type of atmosphere model is available: the adiabatic atmosphere model.

If it gets accepted, this feature would require a new optional section in the world SDF file (see related pull request [#241](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/241/new-element/diff)):

```
#!xml
<world name="default">
  <atmosphere name="default" type="adiabatic">
    <temperature>288.15</temperature> <!-- Temperature at sea level in kelvins -->
    <pressure>101325</pressure> <!-- Pressure at sea level in pascals -->
    <mass_density>1.225</mass_density> <!-- Mass density of the air at sea level in kg/m^3 -->
    <temperature_gradient>-0.0065</temperature_gradient> <!-- Temperature gradient with respect to increasing altitude at sea level in units of K/m -->
  </atmosphere>
</world>
```

At the client side, the atmosphere parameters are displayed in the property tree browser and can be changed dynamically.
values.title: Atmosphere model

summary.raw:
This pull request provides a base class Atmosphere and a derived class AdiabaticAtmosphere that implements an adiabatic atmosphere model.

The global atmosphere parameters are defined in the SDF file, they consist of the temperature, pressure, mass density, and temperature gradient at sea level. The Atmosphere class is instantiated once during World initialization. A plugin can access the Atmosphere singleton with ```World::Atmosphere()``` and query its values at different altitudes. For now, only one type of atmosphere model is available: the adiabatic atmosphere model.

If it gets accepted, this feature would require a new optional section in the world SDF file (see related pull request [#241](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/241/new-element/diff)):

```
#!xml
<world name="default">
  <atmosphere name="default" type="adiabatic">
    <temperature>288.15</temperature> <!-- Temperature at sea level in kelvins -->
    <pressure>101325</pressure> <!-- Pressure at sea level in pascals -->
    <mass_density>1.225</mass_density> <!-- Mass density of the air at sea level in kg/m^3 -->
    <temperature_gradient>-0.0065</temperature_gradient> <!-- Temperature gradient with respect to increasing altitude at sea level in units of K/m -->
  </atmosphere>
</world>
```

At the client side, the atmosphere parameters are displayed in the property tree browser and can be changed dynamically.
summary.html:
This pull request provides a base class Atmosphere and a derived class AdiabaticAtmosphere that implements an adiabatic atmosphere model.

The global atmosphere parameters are defined in the SDF file, they consist of the temperature, pressure, mass density, and temperature gradient at sea level. The Atmosphere class is instantiated once during World initialization. A plugin can access the Atmosphere singleton with World::Atmosphere() and query its values at different altitudes. For now, only one type of atmosphere model is available: the adiabatic atmosphere model.

If it gets accepted, this feature would require a new optional section in the world SDF file (see related pull request #241):

<world name="default">
  <atmosphere name="default" type="adiabatic">
    <temperature>288.15</temperature> <!-- Temperature at sea level in kelvins -->
    <pressure>101325</pressure> <!-- Pressure at sea level in pascals -->
    <mass_density>1.225</mass_density> <!-- Mass density of the air at sea level in kg/m^3 -->
    <temperature_gradient>-0.0065</temperature_gradient> <!-- Temperature gradient with respect to increasing altitude at sea level in units of K/m -->
  </atmosphere>
</world>

At the client side, the atmosphere parameters are displayed in the property tree browser and can be changed dynamically.

values.description:
pull request #1967 refactored `ArrowVisuals` to use child visuals instead of directly creating ogre scene nodes but did not indicate that the child visuals don't need to be updated by the RTShaderSystem.  This caused the load time for complex robots like PR2 that has lots of joints to load forever. 

This PR:

- sets the `userRTShader` flag to false for child visuals of `ArrowVisual`

- Optmized RTShaderSystem to call `Update` only once per update loop since its an expensive operation.


[gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/634/) - ok
values.title: Update shaders once per render update -> gazebo6

This PR:

values.description:
Thanks to the great improvements on playback speed done on pull request #1931, it's now feasible to jump to a specific moment in time on the log.

* Now the current time is editable

![log_edit_time.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2204722306-log_edit_time.png)

* Time is skipped to the closest available sample, just like dragging the line.

* If the user input doesn't respect the format, we stay at the current time

* It's not possible to load logs on QTests yet, so there's no test for `LogPlayWidget`.
values.title: Enter time during log playback

summary.raw:
Thanks to the great improvements on playback speed done on pull request #1931, it's now feasible to jump to a specific moment in time on the log.

* Now the current time is editable

![log_edit_time.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2204722306-log_edit_time.png)

* Time is skipped to the closest available sample, just like dragging the line.

* If the user input doesn't respect the format, we stay at the current time

* It's not possible to load logs on QTests yet, so there's no test for `LogPlayWidget`.
summary.html:
Thanks to the great improvements on playback speed done on pull request #1931, it's now feasible to jump to a specific moment in time on the log.

  • Now the current time is editable

  • Time is skipped to the closest available sample, just like dragging the line.

  • If the user input doesn't respect the format, we stay at the current time

  • It's not possible to load logs on QTests yet, so there's no test for LogPlayWidget.

values.description:
I'm having a problem using `SetWidgetReadOnly` with some custom widgets. My problem is fixed by this patch to `ConfigWidget`.

I've been trying to write a test to reproduce the issue but the tests keep on passing even without the patch. I've tried to copy almost the same situation which is failing for me but, while it fails for me, it passes for the tests.

So instead of spending more time trying to make the test fail, I decided to make the pull request with the passing test. I guess at least the test shows that nothing is broken...

[no gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/860/) is happy
